statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={\left({4}^{{{x}-{2}}}\right)}+{4}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={\left({4}^{{{x}-{2}}}\right)}+{4} has \displaystyle+{4} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={4}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle{x}-{2}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}={2}. Here \displaystyle{y}={5}.
A second convenient point is one right of 2, which is \displaystyle{x}={3}. Here \displaystyle{y}={8}
